title: Alpers Disease: Progressive Neurologic Disorder in Childhood
short_description: Clinical overview of Alpers disease, a rare progressive neurologic disorder affecting children with symptoms including seizures, spasticity, cognitive decline, and potential liver complications.
long_description: This document provides a comprehensive clinical description of Alpers disease, a rare progressive neurologic disorder that typically manifests in early childhood between 3 months and 5 years of age. The condition is characterized by a complex constellation of neurological symptoms including seizures, spasticity with exaggerated reflexes, motor coordination deficits, and progressive cognitive decline leading to dementia. The document details the clinical presentation, which includes muscle tone abnormalities (hypotonia with apparent stiffness), partial paralysis, and muscle twitching. Neuroimaging findings show increased grey matter density on MRI. The disorder frequently involves hepatic complications ranging from jaundice to complete liver failure and cirrhosis. Additional complications may include optic atrophy leading to blindness and progression to spastic quadriplegia in advanced stages. The document notes that while the condition affects both sexes equally, diagnostic challenges make accurate prevalence estimates difficult, with an estimated frequency of less than 1 in 200,000 individuals.
